I am the member for Capricornia because Central Queensland is my home and it is the part of Australia that I care about and want to pour my heart, energy and aspirations into. It is an honour and an exciting challenge to represent the electorate of Capricornia in this place. The electorate of Capricornia extends from the beautiful Capricorn Coast and Shoalwater Bay on the Central Queensland coast to the awesome expanse of the outback and towns such as Winton, Muttaburra, Longreach, Barcaldine, Aramac, Jericho and Alpha. It also includes the mining towns of the Bowen Basin, such as Moranbah, Dysart, Tieri, Middlemount, Cappella, Clermont and Glenden and Collinsville, which is a town that has a particularly strong Labor heritage. The major city of my electorate is my home of Rockhampton.
Capricornia is indeed an enormous electorate with a spirit to match. It is an electorate full of character as well as its fair share of 
 characters. The electorate of Capricornia has a proud history that belongs to both the traditional owners of our region and to those of us who have made it our home. It is not a history of purely academic interest but a living history, because the products of that history endure today as important symbols and institutions of our country. I am talking of things such as Qantas, which was conceived at a meeting in Winton and launched from a dusty airstrip in Longreach. Waltzing Matilda was written at Dagworth station and first performed at the North Gregory hotel in Winton.
Of course there is the Australian Labor Party. The architects of the last redistribution perhaps would not have known the historical significance of the lines they drew. In fact, the boundary of the Capricornia electorate covers Clermont, Barcaldine and Rockhampton. All three centres played a significant role in Labor history. The Ballad of 1891, a long-held hymn of the working class, especially in Queensland, tells it all with lines such as:
From Clermont to Barcaldine the shearers' song rang out—the sheds'll be shore union or they won't be shore at all.
There is also:
To trial at Rockhampton the 14 men were brought. The judge had got his orders—the squatters owned the court. But for every man that was sentenced a 1000 won't forget—where you jail a man for striking it's a rich man's country yet.
No doubt some of my colleagues will want to argue this point and claim that the birthplace of our party is Sydney or Melbourne. However, the tree of knowledge in Barcaldine stands as a testament to the claim that the Australian Labor Party was born in Capricornia.
There can, however, be no dispute about the statement that Capricornia boasts many wonderful achievements. Wool grown on the backs of our sheep out west and shorn by local shearers such as John Laffin finds itself woven into the highest quality suits. Beef mustered out of the gullies and downs from Winton to Westwood, from Longreach to Lockington and from Aramac to Alton Downs graces the best dining tables in the world and 
 gives my home of Rockhampton its much deserved title of the beef capital of Australia.
Coal dug from Capricornia's soil by hardworking coalminers makes our region one of Australia's richest exporters. The Central Queensland University is a progressive and successful institution that provides high quality educational and research facilities to our region and beyond as well as playing a leading role in our community. Great Keppel Island and the towns of the spectacular Capricorn Coast welcome increasing numbers of Australian and international tourists each year. Just up the road is Shoalwater Bay, a training area used by our Australian armed forces and one that regularly hosts exercises with our neighbours, such as the Singaporeans who have spent the last couple of months training  there.
There is no doubt that our region of Central Queensland has great potential to build on our fine history. I wonder, though, whether this government knows what it is doing to crush the traditional spirit of the people of Capricornia. When I listen to people in the communities around the electorate, I share their feeling that this government has abandoned us in regional Australia. The coalition government apparently sees no role for itself in ensuring that the gains made by our country and the standard of living available to Australians are evenly distributed. The No. 1 issue for us in Capricornia has to be jobs: creating new jobs and providing security for those in work.
So what does the Howard government give us? It gives us an industrial relations regime that threatens the wages, conditions and security of workers and cutbacks to the public sector in our region. I spoke before about the history of Capricornia being a living history. There were parts of that history that we thought would never have to be relived: the times in our history when workers were gaoled and denied livelihoods for themselves and their families simply because they were members of a union. It appears that those times are alive and well in Capricornia. Just ask my mate Garry Barnes, the president of the Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union in Clermont, one of 16 unionists at 
 the Blair Athol coalmine currently engaged in an unfair dismissal claim against Rio Tinto after losing their jobs shortly after refusing to sign individual contracts.
I have stood shoulder to shoulder with miners on picket lines around Capricornia while they struggle against the government's ideological allies, like Rio Tinto and Arco, to protect their jobs and that most basic right of workers, the right to form a union and bargain collectively. I have stood in the smoko rooms at the meatworks in Rocky and listened to the workers there talk about their fears of the future in a workplace where the award has been stripped back to nothing.
When the government talks of union members, it seems that it regards them as some kind of breed apart from the rest of society. The government's narrow ideological view of the world does not let it see that union members cannot be cleanly removed from a workplace with some kind of surgical precision without there being residual damage to a community. I am thinking in particular of the mining towns in Capricornia. The union members who are being attacked there are my friends, and I know them to be the local footy coaches, scout leaders and school P&C presidents. They have wives and children. They are the people who spend their pay packets on groceries and Christmas presents at the local businesses. You cannot attack these people without attacking the whole community.
It is not only the government's industrial relations policies that are hurting Capricornia. Over the past two years we have also seen the decline of government services in our region. We have seen the Taxation Office close in Rocky and Telstra workers retrenched. When the CES office closed in Longreach, there was nothing there with which to replace it. The people of Capricornia need these services just as much as those living in capital cities need them.
It is the regional areas that suffer the most from the government's agenda of downsizing and privatising because the market that is supposed to fill the gaps is not interested in us. We cost too much and eat up profits. We rely on the government taking some responsi 
 bility for keeping our communities functioning and providing services to those who need them.
The government is clearly not listening to people in regional areas. If it were listening, it would not have announced two weeks ago that we can expect more job losses at our local Centrelink office. The sick and disabled, the unemployed and the elderly people of Capricornia know exactly what that means for them—a decrease in services. The business people of Capricornia know exactly what it means for them too—fewer pay packets in our towns to keep our local economy ticking over.
In Capricornia we have seen the same thing over and over—promises of increased competition and efficiency that amount to nothing but the slashing of jobs and the decline of services. Whether it is the sale of Telstra or the deregulation of Australia Post, the message from my electorate is clear.
I have wasted no time in bringing these issues into this chamber because they are the issues that I campaigned on and they are the issues that the people of Capricornia expect me to pursue on their behalf. Wherever I go in the electorate—whether it be the Rocky railway workshops, the Lakes Creek meatworks, the Longreach RSL, the Middlemount Bowls Club or Pat Ogden's Globe Hotel—the people of Capricornia have had a gutful of economic policies that are advocated by people who have never even heard of Alpha or Jericho or St Laurence. The people of Capricornia are not interested in fitting into anyone's economic model; they want to be proud of their local communities and not feel penalised because they do not live in the city.
Most of the things that I will say in this place will be spoken on behalf of the people of Capricornia. Right now, though, I would like to say a few words that are mine alone, and they are words that come from the bottom of my heart. I want to pay tribute to the people who gave so much of themselves to get me here. I will never forget or take for granted the support and assistance that I received from local ALP branch members in Capricornia—people like Robert Schwarten and Barry Large and their families; people like Bronco Smith, Marilyn Tynan, Sam 
 Morris, Jim Pearce, Pat Ogden, Stephen Schwarten, Jeff Jones and Mary Therese Brady.
It was especially touching for me to have the support of the family of the late George Gray, the member for Capricornia from 1961 to 1967. Thank you to Bray, Linda, Trish, Jeanne, Don and Rick. One branch member, Joan Brady, deserves a special thank you for being there right from the start. Thank you, Joan, for having faith in a 27-year-old woman long before anyone else got quite used to the idea.
My local branch members have a dedication to their party and a commitment to their communities that I hope I can live up to. From its inception, the Labor Party has been the political voice of the union movement; I will certainly continue that role as the member for Capricornia. During the campaign my brothers and sisters in the union movement showed that they truly understand the meaning of solidarity. The support from unions—like the Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union; the Australian Liquor, Hospitality and Miscellaneous Workers Union; the Australian Meat Industry Employees Union; the Australian Manufacturing Workers Union; the Queensland Nurses Union; the National Tertiary Education Union; the Communications, Electrical and Plumbing Union; my old employer, the Community and Public Sector Union; and others—was absolutely rock solid and an important part of Labor's victory in Capricornia. I would also like to pay tribute to the members of Emily's List for their support and motivation throughout my time as a political candidate.
It does feel sometimes that the Labor Party has become my family—it has become such a big part of my life—but it can never compare to the wonderful family that has given me so much love and support over the last 29 years of my life. Thank you to my mother, Desley, and my sister Heidi, who is here today, and my little sister Sascha. My grandparents—Richard and Beryl White in Mackay, and Roy and Clara Livermore in Ipswich—also played a big part in giving me the values and motivation to make this journey.
Compared with these people, my partner, Craig Brown, is a relative newcomer. But the last 3½ years that he has shared with me have been the most tumultuous and fulfilling of my life: you're my best mate—I couldn't have done it without you, and I wouldn't have wanted to.
I finish today with a pledge to work my heart out for the people of my electorate. As the member for Capricornia, I will work with the communities in the electorate to build on our traditional strengths and always be on the lookout for new opportunities for our region. I cannot promise miracles, but I promise hard work, determination and complete honesty of conviction in trying to deliver to the people of Capricornia a secure future.

name: Katter, Bob, Jnr, MP
text:
—The previous speaker, the honourable member for Capricornia, spoke very eloquently and very movingly. It was somewhat distressing that she had not done a little more study—
Opposition members interjecting—
—Order! The honourable member for Kennedy has the floor. He will examine his own conscience at a later date.
—Yes, that is correct. I appreciate young people having their dreams and their aspirations. I think that is an important thing, but let me say that in Queensland when 23,000 railwaymen stood in the hot sun and handed out how to vote cards for the ALP they believed in that organisation. Within four years of their great party gaining office in the state of Queensland, there were not 23,000 of them; there were 14,000 of them. In the last 10 years of the government of which I was a part—and I take great pride in saying this—we lost 1,000 jobs in the railway. They went from 23,000 to 22,000. In the first four years of Labor 22,000 railwaymen became 13,000. If those little towns are dying at the moment, it is because those services were removed by the Labor government. In fact, the people of western Queensland created the labour movement and what we got for it was the destruction of our own homeland. 
An interesting analogy can be drawn from the comments of the last speaker. She said that Mr Whitlam was the person who got her into parliament, and that was also true of me because Mr Whitlam got me into parliament. She spoke about the right and the ability to be able to get her way to university. I think there was some merit in what occurred there. In my day I went to university. I went to university because I went home after I finished school and worked 72 hours a week. I worked from nine to five in my father's clothing shop, and then in the evening I worked at our picture theatre six nights a week. I worked very hard and saved up to go away to university.
Opposition members interjecting—
—Order! I can understand and appreciate the exuberance coming from the opposition benches, but I have given the call to the honourable member for Kennedy. He will be heard in silence.
—It obviously hurts them, Madam Deputy Speaker. I can understand the pain. As for what we did, every single thing that the previous speaker described was not done by the current government at all. Enterprise bargaining was not introduced by us. Enterprise bargaining, which undermined the right of the worker to collectively bargain, was introduced by Mr Keating. Who was it who flew foreign scabs to strikebreak into this country and gave them fast visas to be able to do it? It was not this government; it was the Keating government. Who removed all the tariffs in this country?
Opposition members interjecting—
—I am talking about the pilots. Are you saying that this is incorrect? Of course you are not. You agree with it, but you would not be game to say it. The economic rationalists were not on this side of the House. All of that legislation was introduced by those on that side of the House when they were sitting on this side of the House.
Let me turn to the removal of services. I can hardly think of a town where there has not been a massive removal of services. I have at times been critical of the Borbidge government in Queensland, but I cannot think of a single service that it removed in my old 
 state electorate of Flinders. Yet in my own home town of Cloncurry there were six services removed.
—You want to bring back Bjelke-Petersen, do you? Are you a `Joh for PM' man?
—I will answer your question by saying that we took 1,000 railway jobs away in 10 years; your mob took 10,000 jobs away in 3½ years. You should not have walked into that one, should you?
I would like to draw to the attention of this House the suicide rate in this country. From 1971 to 1996 male suicides in this country have doubled, and for young men they have increased by some 300 per cent. Australia is now second only to Russia, which has the highest suicide rate for young men in the entire world. Unemployment in 1971 was 1.7 per cent. Unemployment in Australia today is 7.7 per cent, some 700 per cent higher than it was in 1971. I have some figures on the growth in our gaols in Queensland. I do not have the figures for Australia as a whole. In 1971 there were 1,236 in our gaols. In 1996 there were 3,528 people, an increase of some 300 per cent. Even more amazing is the rise in bankruptcies. In 1971 there were 2,428 bankruptcies. Today in Australia bankruptcies total 24,000.
The previous speaker attributed all the ills in this country to the current government. I am afraid that over the last 15 years we have been in government for only 2½ years. If there are a lot of ills in this country, she should take it up with her current leadership, all of whom were on the frontbench during the period when bankruptcies in Australia rose from about 4,500 to some 20,000. The policies that they put in train during those years are still crucifying the country today. It will be some years before the effects of those policies abate.
Having looked at those grim statistics and having reflected upon the fact that small business in Australia is almost a vanishing and dying race, I would like to quote but one example. There were 17,000 privately owned service stations in Australia before Mr Keating—the great architect of economic rationalist policy in this place—decided to 
 half-deregulate the service stations. He half-deregulated the service stations, and the net result was that 8,000 family businesses in this country ceased to exist. They went broke and closed their doors.
We are talking not only about heartbreak and destruction here but also about an increase in control in the marketplace by the oil companies. From 1984 to the present day, we have seen a rise in the price of petrol paid to the oil companies from 12c a litre in 1984 to around 22c a litre today—almost a doubling of the price paid to the oil companies for petrol. In that same period of time, the price for a barrel of oil has dropped from around $38 to about $15 or $16. So the world price has dropped clean in half and the price in Australia has doubled. Clearly, the cost to the nation of that act of deregulation has been colossal.
We look for reasons as to why we have a horrific 300-fold increase in the number of people in our gaols and a 250 per cent increase in the number of young male suicides. The previous speaker, the member for Capricornia, gave a very sensitive and a very good address, but I would ask people in these cases: if you are going to stand up and put forward propositions, back them up. It is not good enough to come in here and just make some bland statements without hard factual evidence to back them up.
I have a gold file here with me, and I can give the source document for each of the figures that I am quoting here. The graph on page 28 of the document I have here tells the story on unemployment, unhappiness and sadness in this country. There is a graph showing the growth in unemployment amongst young males from 1966 to 1996, and there is a similar graph for the growth in the suicide rate amongst that same cohort of population from 1966 to 1996. It is a truly remarkable document, because the graphs cannot be separated; they are almost identical. The rise in unemployment amongst young males has been identical to the rise in youth suicides in this country. So, if you are looking for an answer for all of this dreadful unhappiness, look no further than jobs.
When people like Mr Whitlam reduced tariff protection by 25 per cent across the board, it cost Australia hundreds of thousands of jobs and burnt out so much opportunity that could have existed in this country. I am not saying that there was not a case for reducing tariffs, and I am not saying that there was not a case for reducing tariffs significantly. But to hit them with a blunt instrument of 25 per cent, and then proceed—in the years of the Hawke-Keating government—to remove all tariffs, was one of the greatest examples of supine trading policy espoused by any country anywhere in the world. I see the honourable member for Dickson grinning. I am sure that she would agree with everything I am saying here, as she has on many occasions.
It can well be argued that economic rationalism, and the removal of all of those protections, was a good thing internationally. But, unfortunately, the other countries in the world have not done that. To take the example of one of the industries I represent, the tariff on sugar has been completely removed, and that allows the biggest sugar exporter in the world, the European Community, to send its sugar into Australia with a subsidy equivalent to 193 per cent.
We have been given little talks about free trade in this place during the four years that I have been in here and in the 12 years before that, two of which were under Mr Keating. They did not cut much ice with me, as a person who has owned cattle all of my adult life. I was not very convinced, because only 7,000 tonnes of beef are allowed into the European Community—a market of arguably 500 million or 600 million people. One of my neighbours—one person in Australia—would produce 7,000 tonnes a year. A number of people will each produce more than 7,000 tonnes of beef a year. Yet we have played fair game while the other side have played snake and goannas. They must be laughing at us.
The previous speaker attributed to this government decisions it had nothing to do with. All of those decisions were taken prior to this government taking office. We could not remove any tariffs, because there were no tariffs left to remove. There was nothing left 
 for us to do. She said that we are grinding the worker down. But enterprise bargaining was introduced by the previous government. If the worker is being ground down as a result of enterprise bargaining, we had nothing to do with that. And she said that any further action taken by us will worsen this situation. But enterprise bargaining is here now. We can do whatever needs to be done, but it will not have much effect, because it already exists.
In the seven minutes left, I would like to quickly go through the solutions. We have this horrific suicide rate and we have this terribly high unemployment rate, and I cannot help but make the point to the House that David Kemp, when he was opposition spokesman on employment, quoted the real unemployment figure at around 19 per cent—and he had a breakdown of that figure. I thought that was a very good analysis. The OECD report on employment in Australia gives similar figures. Dr John Langmore, who was a member of parliament for some time—in fact he was chairman of the caucus economics committee of the Labor Party—also quoted a figure of around 19 per cent. John Quiggan, the only economist in Australian history to get the Academy of Science prize, also quoted a figure of 19 per cent.
I will tell you how that is arrived at. There were 56,000 people on the CDEP program. These people were taken off the dole and put on a work for the dole scheme in Aboriginal settlements throughout Australia. There were some 200,000 people on Working Nation, and similar schemes have come in. And that is a good thing; I am not criticising them for one moment.
Quiggan and Langmore both make the point that TPI pensions in Australia have increased by 400 per cent. This is undoubtedly true, and I suppose there would be very few of us who do not know people with bad backs—but they do a lot of work at home during the week with their bad backs. I do not blame them for that; I just think that there are no jobs out there for them.
What I am saying is that the real figures are much higher than the indicative figures that we have before us at all times, and I think that David Kemp's analysis in this parliament 
 deserves some looking at by people on both sides of this House if they want to get a true understanding of the nature of unemployment in this country.
There is one thing that this current government has done which has been absolutely magnificent, and it should never be underestimated. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

name: Smith, Stephen, MP
text:
—Labor opposes the full privatisation of Telstra and, as a consequence, opposes the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998  and the package of cognate legislation now before the House. We oppose the package because it effects the full privatisation of Telstra. It effects it through a sham inquiry; it effects it through sleight of hand; it effects it through maximum damage to rural and regional Australia—and the National Party should be ashamed that they have sat on their hands since the election, sat on their hands in the joint party room and done nothing to stand up for the interests of rural and regional Australia—and that includes the 
 Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Mr Vaile, who is at the table, and some of the new members of the National Party who have now fled the chamber.
In particular, this applies to the members for Dawson and Kennedy—who, in the run-up to the last election, made great play of standing up for the interests of rural and regional Australia and made great play of the fact that they did not want to see Telstra fully privatised. I notice that they are on the list of speakers, and so I hope that, when they come and make their contributions, the member for Kennedy and the member for Dawson will create the same impression in this House as they created in their electorates in the run-up to the election: in other words, that they oppose the full privatisation of Telstra and cross the floor on the bill.
I assume that, at the joint party meeting at which government members approved this legislation, when National Party members saw the senior Liberal Senator from Tasmania they said, `Dr Watson, I presume', because Senator Watson from Tasmania has been the only member of the coalition since the election—the only member—to say the truth about this package of measures. He said on 8 November in Tasmania that he did not believe that Telstra ought to be fully privatised, and he was reported on the ABC on 8 November as saying that there was majority support in the coalition for limiting further privatisation of Telstra.
He said that the government needed to develop more of a social conscience during this term of office, and that there was widespread community concern about the ability of a fully privatised Telstra to maintain its community service obligations to regional and remote areas. I repeat: `widespread community concern' about the ability of a fully privatised Telstra to maintain its community service obligations to regional and remote areas—areas that the National Party purports to represent.
On the following day, 9 November, in the Australian Financial Review, Senator Watson's attitude was reported thus:
In a further embarrassment to the Government, Senator Watson also cast doubt on whether Telstra 
 would be fully privatised in the foreseeable future. He said his position against a full sale had sufficient support from his government colleagues to ensure it did not go ahead.
This is despite Mr Howard being committed to a full sale of Telstra.
He was also reported as saying that `he saw no reason to move from the 49 per cent sale of Telstra' and that `this position had enough support among his colleagues to ensure there was no full sale in the foreseeable future.'
Well, they all disappeared at the joint party room meeting; they all disappeared. And when the members for Kennedy and Dawson come into this chamber, I hope they stand up for their electorates and stand up for the sorts of comments they made in the run-up to the election.
—Were you at the party room meeting?
—The point is, Minister, you were there and you did not stand up for rural and regional Australia. You did not stand up for your constituents. You did not stand up for the people that you purport to represent.
Labor opposes this package. Labor would not have privatised one-third of Telstra, as the government did in the previous parliament. In the run-up to the 1996 election, we made it clear that we opposed the privatisation of Telstra. In the run-up to the 1998 election, we made it clear that we opposed any further sale beyond the one-third that the government disposed of in the course of the last parliament. So Labor has always been opposed, and remains opposed, to the sale of Telstra, and it will not support the sale of any further portion of Telstra, because primarily we believe that Telstra is a vital part of Australia's community, of our economy and of our regional infrastructure.
There are a number of major reasons why it is essential, in our view, for Telstra to remain in public ownership. Firstly, it is a question of national infrastructure, of economic development and jobs. It is clear that Telstra is a very important part of our national infrastructure. It is very important to our economic development and very important to jobs, particularly for rural and regional and 
 remote Australia. And that lies at the heart of our opposition to the package of measures before the House today.
The second reason is that of the dividend which Telstra pays to the Commonwealth. Each year, Telstra generates a return, and those moneys are paid directly to benefit the taxpayer. By keeping Telstra in public hands, the Commonwealth will continue to receive these funds—funds which will grow each year into the future. Once you have flogged it off, you will not get that return in the future: you lose the profit stream that you have built up over a number of years. Once you have flogged it off, it has gone forever, and so that dividend which has been built up over many years and which provides important revenue to the Commonwealth for essential services generally but also essential services for rural and regional Australia will be gone.
The third reason is the services that Telstra provides to rural and regional and remote Australia: essential—and in many cases, historically, uneconomic—services provided to rural and regional Australia, because Australians and parliaments and governments in the past regarded Telstra, or its predecessor, Telecom—or Telecom's predecessor, the PMG—as being essential because people in rural and regional Australia would rely upon Telstra for their telecommunications services. Telstra is the dominant service provider and, if you keep Telstra in public hands, the government retains the right to ensure that adequate service levels and access to up-to-date technology are delivered to all Australians, irrespective of where they live. This is part of the universal service obligations and the community service obligations.
Keeping Telstra in public hands will make sure that, with the move to new technology, we minimise rather than maximise the tyranny of distance, making sure that we do not run the risk of alienating people who live in rural and remote locations in Australia, and that those who live in areas of Australia uneconomic to service have, and continue to have, access to the vital telecommunications services which Telstra has provided.
The next reason is the point of market dominance. There is no question that Telstra 
 has significant market dominance in its area. You can probably mount the argument that the only thing worse than a public instrumentality which has market dominance is a private instrumentality which has market dominance.
Another reason is that historically the PMG and Telecom, in particular, and then Telstra have done public good works in their research activities. They have invested in long-term R&D. As a fully privatised company, they will not do basic research; they will not do the public good research. Already we have seen, in my view, a decline in that since the one-third privatisation. Another important factor is the significant support over the years which Telecom and Telstra have given to the Australian electronic and telecommunications manufacturing industries. There is a grave risk that that support over the years will decline and disappear if Telstra is fully privatised.
The whole focus of the privatisation of Telstra, which is reflected in this package of measures, is that Telstra will move from providing an adequate level of service to the Australian taxpayer to providing a dividend to its shareholders. That is reflected in very substantive terms by the proposed deletion from the Telstra Corporation Act of the capacity of the government of the day to instruct Telstra in accordance with the public interest.
So there are a range of general philosophical and practical reasons why we have opposed the privatisation of Telstra from day one. We opposed it in the run-up to the 1996 election, we opposed it in the parliament in this last term and we went to the election committed to opposing any further sale of Telstra.
This package of bills effectively fully privatises Telstra by sleight of hand. There is no doubt that in the run-up to the last election the government created the impression, both generally and in the various electorates, that if they were returned to office Telstra would be privatised in a staged way, and they unquestionably created the impression that that staging would be by parliamentary approval. Once passed, this package will effectively achieve the full privatisation of 
 Telstra without further reference to this parliament. If parliament approves these bills, that automatically enables the Commonwealth to dispose of up to 49.9 per cent of Telstra and then, by a sham inquiry, without further reference to the parliament, without further reference to parliamentary review, to tick a box to effect the 100 per cent privatisation of Telstra.
It is important to have a look at some of the history. In 1996, when Telstra was in full public ownership, it brought in a profit of $2.2 billion and paid dividends of nearly $1.4 billion to the Commonwealth. That money was used for vital services and infrastructure such as hospitals, schools and nursing homes. As a consequence of the one-third privatisation, one-third of the profits are now directed away from the Commonwealth. Since the privatisation of Telstra, we have seen major restructuring of Telstra—effectively in preparation for full privatisation but also in response to the one-third privatisation—and that has had dramatic consequences for staffing and service levels. Approximately 22,000 employees have been shed and very many of those have been from rural, regional and remote areas.
Customer service standards are in decline. That is not an assertion. All you need to do is have a look at the December 1997 quarterly figures reported by the ACA, the Australian Communications Authority, to see the decline in standards which has occurred as a consequence of the one-third privatisation. There has been greater pressure for the imposition of additional charges for a range of services which Telstra provides—for example, directory assistance calls. All of these are reasons for Telstra remaining in public ownership.
The bills before us effect the full sale of Telstra. As I have said, if passed, these would allow automatically the sale of 49.9 per cent of Telstra and then effect the full privatisation without further reference to the parliament. Ministers Fahey and Alston in the run-up to the election unquestionably created the impression that this would be a package of legislation to sell up to 49.9 per cent and that the government would then come back to the parliament to effect the remaining sale. I am 
 sure this is the impression they have left with their backbench, particularly the National Party backbenchers—or at least I am sure that is the impression the National Party backbenchers are happy to be left with. So it needs to be understood that if this bill passes the parliament then Telstra is gone. If this bill passes the parliament without further reference to the parliament, 100 per cent of Telstra will be disposed of—it will be gone forever.
Senator Alston promised in July when he announced on behalf of the government the so-called `staged disposal' that the staged approach was a consequence of concerns about service standards, particularly in rural, regional and remote Australia. He said:
. . . unless and until the independent inquiry certifies that service levels are adequate, there will be no further sell down beyond 49%.
It was on the strength of this that National Party members and candidates went out to their constituents and their electorates in the run-up to the 3 October election and effectively articulated that there would be a 49.9 per cent sell-off of Telstra before further activity. The member for Dawson, De-Anne Kelly, in August this year said:
People just really want to see Telstra remain in Government hands.
. . .              . . .             . . .
The bottom line is people don't want to see more than 49% sold.
Given that this legislation effects the full privatisation of Telstra, I hope when the member for Dawson comes into this chamber and speaks and when we divide on this package of measures, which we will, that she holds true to that particular comment and a range of other ones that she made in the run-up to the election and votes against these proposals. I have already drawn attention to the comments that Senator Watson from Tasmania made a few weeks ago. Of course there has been deafening silence from all the other members of the government.
I have described the so-called `independent inquiry' on the measures as a `sham inquiry'. The two relevant ministers—the Minister for Finance and Administration, Mr Fahey, and the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston— 
 have always maintained that it was their intention to fully privatise Telstra. The Prime Minister has probably gone furthest of them all. On ABC radio on 27 July, in questioning on the supposed `independent inquiry', he was asked by an ABC reporter, `Is it conceivable that this inquiry would recommend that you don't sell the rest of Telstra and that you won't?' Howard: `No.'
So this is not an inquiry in respect of which the government has an open mind. This is not an inquiry in respect of which you can expect to see independent, impartial and objective assessment of these things. This is not an inquiry the results of which will be subject to review or determination at ministerial, cabinet or parliamentary level. In that same interview, the Prime Minister went on to say:
Well there's certainly been no flip-flop. I can't believe the description of last week's announcement as being a flip-flop. We are still committed to a sale of one hundred per cent of Telstra.
So it will not be an independent inquiry and it will not be a viable, rational or sensible inquiry. If the legislation has effect, it will be a six-month inquiry.
Whatever service levels are required—and these are not detailed in the legislation—you will be dealing with two quarters of data. In my view, two quarters of data is an insufficient period of time to establish any sort of realistic statistical trend. It is not enough to get an indication of Telstra's service performance, particularly for the bush. The ABS handles data on the basis that the only suitable basis for policy analysis or advice is data trend over five quarters or 15 months, which is described technically as the five-term Henderson moving averages technique.
So you have a massively inferior period of time over which data will be collected and assessed. And in the six-month period when Telstra would know they were under the spotlight, so to speak, it would be very easy for them to load up the respective services and, after the inquiry—after a six-month period—effectively let them all fall by the wayside.
So what do we find with respect to the so-called independent inquiry? The government has made it clear from day one that, irrespec 
 tive of what the independent inquiry might say or do, it remains absolutely committed to the full privatisation of Telstra. Secondly, you will not have the period of time during which the data can be properly collected or assessed.
On the day of the announcement of the government's so-called staged sell-off—22 July—the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston, made a speech to the New South Wales Farmers Association Annual Conference, in the course of which he said:
The next thing the Government will do, in the same Bill, is specify performance criteria, against which Telstra's performance will be judged by an independent inquiry which the Government will establish . . . The criteria which will be contained in the legislation . . . 
And you look in the legislation and you cannot find it. Having given a commitment, in the strongest possible terms on the day on which the policy was announced, that the bill would specify the performance criteria—that the criteria would be contained in this legislation—when you flick through the legislation you do not find it.
The criteria will be effected by regulation. You effect the full privatisation of Telstra by having this bill passed and then having a sham inquiry on criteria not seen by this parliament. You effect the full privatisation of Telstra by a sham inquiry working on the basis of regulations, despite an expressed and absolute commitment by the minister that those criteria would be contained in the legislation. And what do we hear from the National Party—Dr Watson, I presume—nothing; deafening silence. The inquiry is basically a sham. It is a tick the box. It is a rubber stamp. There is no reference back to the parliament, and they seek to slide this through without scrutiny.
I found an interesting quotation from the member for Kennedy, Mr Katter, which I am sure he will be only too happy to repeat to the House himself. During July-August, he said:
I must say that I thought it was a fairly arrogant statement and it most certainly indicated to me that they are determined not to withdraw in any way, shape or form . . . it seems to me their intention is that there will be some sort of rubber stamp 
 committee to allow them to sell the second half. But I'm not going to go along with that, I can tell you right now.
All you need is the words of a member of this parliament, a member of the National Party: a `rubber stamp committee to allow them to sell the second half'. I hope the member for Kennedy comes into the parliament in the course of this week, repeats those comments and votes accordingly when the legislation is the subject of a division.
The package of legislation that the government envelopes around the sham inquiry has the government saying, `It will all be okay because we have a whole range of community obligations and consumer protection provisions that we have put in,' the vast bulk of which are status quo ante in any event. The government says it is okay and, `Look, this package is there to protect standards.' But all you need to do is look at the Australian Communications Authority performance monitoring data for the December 1997 quarter, which you find in the March 1998 Performance Monitoring Bulletin from the ACA, to find the decline of services that we have seen since Telstra was privatised by one-third—and don't expect that you would not see a similar or worse decline in services on the basis of a full privatisation.
Telstra's performance in the provision of new services in country areas declined by nine per cent to 66 per cent during the quarter ending 31 December 1997. This was a 16 per cent reduction on the quarter ending 31 December 1996. So you have a nine per cent decline following a 16 per cent decline. Telstra's performance in country areas in the number of faults cleared within one day also fell during the December 1997 quarter by seven per cent to 61 per cent, and this was a 13 per cent reduction on the December 1996 quarter. The percentage of faults cleared within two days fell by six per cent to 80 per cent during the December 1997 quarter, and by 10 per cent when compared with the December 1996 quarter.
The clearing of faults with payphones in country areas was even worse. The number of faults with public payphones which were cleared within one day fell by 14 per cent to 
 47 per cent during the December 1997 quarter and 20 per cent when compared with the December 1996 quarter.
Telstra explains each of these reductions in service usually in terms of organisational changes or inclement weathers, but even the minister for communications, Senator Alston, was forced to acknowledge that this performance was simply not good enough. So you find in the performance monitoring data of the ACA—the relevant regulatory authority—that there is a whole series of decline in services for country and rural and remote areas on the basis of a one-third privatisation of Telstra.
One of the important things that you lose with the package of measures that we find before the House and with the full privatisation of Telstra is the capacity of the government of the day or the minister of the day to intervene and direct Telstra in the national interest. There has been a very interesting history to this provision. The government in the previous parliament introduced its legislation to privatise one-third of Telstra in the Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill 1996. It was introduced by the then member for Bass who is no longer with us—
Mr Martin interjecting—
—He is no longer with us, but he is doing well. But I do not think he will pop up on this occasion as the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman.
Mr Vaile interjecting—
—He is in Sydney. Just like the National Party members in this parliament, he is not necessarily standing up to the Sydney and Melbourne lawyers at this point in the cycle. On 2 May in his second reading speech the then member for Bass said:
The bill repeals the power contained in section 9 of the Telstra Corporation Act 1991 for the minister to give directions to Telstra in the national interest, from the date of sale of the first shares. Retention of the power post part sale would be overly intrusive and incongruous with moving Telstra into a more commercial framework.
So at the first opportunity this government sought to delete from the Telstra Corporation Act the power of the government of the day 
 to instruct Telstra. Fortunately, through amendments moved on our behalf in the Senate and accepted ultimately by the government in this chamber, that power was reinstated and remains within the Telstra Corporation Act to this day.
 This package of measures seeks to abolish it and seeks—again by sleight of hand—to create the impression that it is replaced with a somewhat comparable power. What it is actually replaced with is a very limited power, which is effectively a power on the part of a minister to require Telstra to comply with the law. What you lose is the capacity of the minister of the day to direct Telstra to do things which, in public policy terms, are in the public interest in the positive sense or to require Telstra to do things which are in the public interest in the negative sense by rectifying past wrongs or ill deeds.
 So the very important capacity on the part of the Commonwealth to influence public policy is thrown out by the full privatisation of Telstra. And make no mistake, the full privatisation of Telstra and the removal of the power of the minister to direct in the public interest will see only one thing occurring: Telstra operating in a fully commercial way without regard to the sorts of historical obligations we have seen to rural, regional and remote Australia and without the sorts of obligations we have seen by way of community service obligations and universal service arrangements.
There are a couple of other points I might make in respect of the privatisation process. Under the legislation the privatisation process follows the same framework as the privatisation of one-third of Telstra—I note on the speakers' list that my colleague the member for Melbourne, the shadow minister for finance, is speaking as well; I am sure he will make great play of these points. The privatisation process for one-third of Telstra has been the subject of very ferocious, serious criticisms by the Auditor-General.
It is unquestionably the case from the Auditor-General's report that, if you do the calculations, the cost of the sale of one-third of Telstra effectively ran $65 million over budget, and excessive fees were paid to sales 
 managers. The report highlighted a litany of administrative incompetence by the government which has been of direct benefit to sales managers. There is a cursory mention in the explanatory memorandum that these comments will be taken on board. That belied the demeanour and appearance of the Minister for Finance and Administration in question time last week when these things were put to him, where he did his best to effectively put his head in the sand and to ignore the fact that these deficiencies had occurred.
 There are a number of measures in the legislation package which the government touts as being significant consumer protection or competition measures. But, in the main, these reflect the status quo ante; they are unremarkable and uncontentious. If dealt with in isolation separate from the ownership question, then they might easily be able to be seriously considered and generally agreed to. But because they form part of the veil of sham, of sliding through without effective scrutiny, creating the impression that this is a sale of 49 per cent of Telstra when it affects the full privatisation of Telstra, we are proposing to oppose the package in its entirety en bloc.
 One of the measures in the Telstra bill itself is the suggestion to require the appointment of two members of the Telstra board who have rural and regional experience. That is the best concession the National Party could get out of the Melbourne and Sydney lawyers in this piece of legislation.
The real question here is, in a sense, the social obligations that historically we have seen with Telstra. The government says that a range of social bonuses will apply from the proceeds of the sale of Telstra. In the main, these last either as a one-off, over a period of three years or over a period of five years. After the five-year period is extinguished, what is the government going to do to ensure that uneconomic services continue to regions like the bush? There is no ministerial power to direct in the public interest. The one-off so-called social bonus from the proceeds has gone. It comes to a total of $671 million—not a sum to be sneezed at—but, in 1996, the last year of dividend returned to the government 
 prior to the privatisation of Telstra, we saw a dividend of nearly $1.4 billion paid to the Commonwealth. So in the year before privatisation there was a dividend of $1.4 billion and now we find the so-called social bonus is some $671 million in total. If you spread that over a period of five years, you get an expenditure of about $134 million per year, which is about 10 or 11 per cent of the dividend that I have referred to.
 Once the social bonus is gone, what is there to hold in place the services to rural, regional and remote Australia? Not a great deal. Senator Harradine from Tasmania has found in recent days the very grave difficulties of trying to make sure that promises, commitments and undertakings given in respect of jobs and services to an area like Tasmania are very hard to keep up to the mark once you unleash the privatisation forces. The capacity on the part of Senator Harradine or any other member of this House or the Senate to influence and affect Telstra will go out of the window with the full privatisation and the removal of the power to direct.
In the Australian of 13 November, I noticed a front page story by Mark Westfield entitled `Telstra sale threat' which reads:
Telstra's board might try to block the Federal Government's proposed further sale of shares in the carrier if the horse-trading over votes in the Senate threatens to damage the company commercially.
Then on page 21 Westfield in a comment piece goes into more detail and makes the point that the board is concerned about community service or universal obligations being placed on it. Nothing better could illustrate the dynamic and the difficulty of trying to keep in place the universal access arrangements and the community service obligations if this package of measures was enacted.
When we get down the speakers list to the members for Dawson and Kennedy, I hope we see them standing up and making the same sorts of comments they made to their constituents in the run-up to the last election. I hope they stand up and say, `We do not want to authorise a sale beyond 49 per cent.' I hope we see them cross the floor. This is a package 
 of measures which effects the full privatisation of Telstra. It does it by a sham inquiry. It does it without effective reference to the parliament or review by the parliament. We oppose these measures absolutely. (Time expired)

name: Somlyay, Alex, MP
text:
—When members of the Labor Party stand up to speak in this debate, I hope they declare whether they took the opportunity to buy Telstra shares when the float was made. It would be very interesting to check the register of members' interests. I have not done so but I am sorely tempted. There are a few matters which in recent times have ignited emotions in regional and rural Australia more than the question of privatisation of Telstra. Let me make the position very clear from this side of the House: the proposed sale was not and is not motivated by ideology. No-one on this side of the House wants to sell Telstra for mere ideological reasons.
The Prime Minister announced before the 1996 election, not after the election, that a coalition government would sell one-third of Telstra. We were open and honest about Telstra before the election. We did not make the announcement without a mandate, as Labor did with their plan to sell the Commonwealth Bank. Labor sold the Commonwealth Bank without a mandate. Not a word was said before the 1993 election about Labor's intention to sell the Commonwealth Bank. Labor sold the Commonwealth Bank by stealth. We sought a mandate from the Australian people before we sold one-third of Telstra, a mandate which the people gave us by the strongest acclamation—a resounding victory at the 1996 election.
This mandate was supported by the people of regional Australia. In the last parliament, the coalition held 61 seats which were wholly or partially rural or regional, as against the ALP's 11 seats. We had the one-third privatisation of Telstra firmly on the agenda. Although we had a mandate, Labor opposed the sale of Telstra and frustrated the passage of the legislation in the Senate.
I said that the coalition, in opposition and in government, were not driven by ideology in proposing to the Australian people that we 
 partially privatise Telstra. Why would anybody sell an income producing asset? Why would an individual want to sell his or her income producing asset? Why would business people propose to sell their assets, especially income producing assets? Why would a government propose to sell an income producing asset? One obvious reason to sell an income producing asset is that you have to—not `want to' but `have to'.
What is being lost in this debate is that the government had little choice but to propose to sell Telstra if it were to be judged fiscally responsible. We had to pay off government debt. Remember that that debt was Labor's debt. Successive Hawke and Keating governments accumulated $95 billion of government debt in six or seven years during the 1990s. The stark reality is that Labor's debt had to be paid off. Some of it has been paid off but more remains to be paid off. Therefore, one reason to propose to sell an income producing asset is to retire debt. That point is reached when the cost of servicing that debt becomes unmanageable.
When we came to office, public debt interest was running at $9.1 billion. The member for Perth pointed out to the House that the income the government received through the dividend stream from Telstra was $1.4 billion. Debt servicing costs were $9.1 billion. In other words, our capacity to implement our programs—provide hospitals, health and other services—was limited by interest payments of over $9 billion on Labor's debt every year. Before we could spend one cent on social services—welfare, defence, roads—we had to spend $9.1 billion on interest payments on Labor's debt.
Another reason to propose to sell an income producing asset is to give yourself the financial capacity to invest in other income producing assets. The government has done a combination of these two things. We proposed before the 1996 election to sell one-third of Telstra because we were forced to address Labor's legacy of debt. We used part of the proceeds to retire a significant amount of that debt. The amount we did not use to pay off Labor's debt we have used for investment in national and regional development through the 
 Federation Fund and the Natural Heritage Fund. Most of that $2 billion investment went into infrastructure and rebuilding rural and regional Australia.
After the sale of one-third of Telstra is Australia better off or worse off? Many Australians invested in the share float. Are they better off or worse off? Members on both sides of this House hold Telstra shares, and so they should. Everyone who invested in Telstra shares is better off today, including the employees of Telstra who had the opportunity to invest in the future performance of their employer. Are the people and the hundreds of regional communities that benefited from the excellent works funded from the Natural Heritage Fund and the Federation Fund worse off? I know they are not worse off. I know that local councils and communities are far better off from the investments made from the proceeds of the sale of the initial one-third of Telstra.
In the last budget in my previous capacity I tabled a statement on government expenditure in regional Australia which showed an annual expenditure of $3.2 billion on programs which were non-existent under the previous government—that is, $3.2 billion of expenditure in rural and regional Australia that was non-existent under the previous government. That was new expenditure, new programs and new investment creating new employment in the bush. This could not have been possible without the sale of one-third of Telstra. Would Australia have been better off without that quality infrastructure? Of course not. The reality is that without the sale of Telstra the government could not have funded the quality infrastructure so essential to the competitiveness of regional businesses and the quality of life for people living in rural and regional Australia.
I have already mentioned the $1 billion Federation Fund, the bulk of which contributes to national infrastructure. There is also a further $250 million through the Regional Telecommunications Infrastructure Fund and the Roads of National Importance program. The $1.25 billion Natural Heritage Trust is the most integrated and far-reaching package of investment in conservation and natural 
 resource management ever introduced in Australia. We sold part of an income producing asset to retire Labor's debt and to invest in a whole range of other income and job producing assets, particularly in regional Australia.
Who then are the losers from the privatisation of Telstra? Who is worse off? Through scaremongering and misinformation, Labor has created a sea of unrest about the privatisation of Telstra. The implication of this and the doubt created by those such as One Nation is that people in regional Australia have been scared into believing that a full sale of Telstra would result in a fall in standards of service in the bush. When you look at the investment in the bush from the one-third sale of Telstra, people are far better off, not worse off. You can see where the money went and where the money is going. Interest on debt is down. Communication services in the bush have been boosted as never before.
I contrast this with Labor's record. They have opposed the sale of Telstra all the way with ideological passion. But Labor sold Qantas and Labor sold the Commonwealth Bank. What has Australia to show for the sale of these assets? Did Labor sell those income producing assets to pay off debt? The answer is an emphatic no. Debt went up during and after those sales, not down. Did Labor use the proceeds to invest in other income producing assets? The answer is again an emphatic no. In fact, not only did government debt accumulate further but Finance Minister Beazley left this government with a $10.3 billion budget deficit on top.
Labor sold Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank, but where did the money go? When we came to office we could not find it. There was no evidence that anyone benefited from Labor's privatisation program because Labor used the money not for investment, not for debt redemption; the proceeds propped up your budget bottom line. You blew the money and Australia has nothing to show for it. Proper economic management by the Howard government, the sale of one-third of Telstra and the responsible use of those proceeds see Australia far better off than in 1996.
I do not want to see further potential benefits disappear. The government will sell another 16 per cent of Telstra to keep faith with those in the community who fear full privatisation will mean a lower standard of services. No more will be sold until we are assured beyond doubt by an independent inquiry that standards will not fall. No-one on this side of the House would contemplate sale further than 49 per cent unless we have ironclad guarantees on standards.
I urge the people of regional Australia to consider the further benefits which will flow from the passage of these bills. The Prime Minister uses the term `social bonus' to describe benefits that will accrue. But I point out to honourable members that the social bonus is, in reality, an investment in infrastructure, our great regions and the people of those regions.
Direct benefits will be an increase in the Natural Heritage Trust by $250 million; rural transaction centres, $70 million over five years; extended access to untimed local calls, $150 million over three years; meeting the telecommunications needs of people in remote and isolated island communities or the Australian Antarctic Territory, $20 million over three years; Internet access for people in rural and regional areas, $36 million over three years; mobile phone coverage along highways, $25 million over three years; and, finally but not least, a television fund to enable improved television reception, extend coverage of SBS television and to support a new media unit to be established within the SBS, $120 million over five years.
In summary, as a member who comes from regional Australia—I have a regional electorate—this package of bills provides an enormous opportunity for this parliament to move towards full private ownership of Telstra and to enable the government to enter the next century without a debt problem while at the same time investing in our people and our regions. The bills also give the people of regional Australia—in fact, all Australians—ironclad guarantees on consumer service standards, customer service standards, transparency and many other safeguards. I therefore commend these bills to the House.

name: Tanner, Lindsay, MP
text:
—Before we give consideration to the sale of the next tranche of Telstra, I want to make some observations about what has happened with the first tranche and then I will turn to some of the specifics associated with this bill, the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998 , some of the broader questions of the privatisation of Telstra and also the purported justification for this—the question of Australia's debt.
The Auditor-General conducted an inquiry into the sale of the first tranche of Telstra and he had some very interesting findings. He found in an overall sense that there was a $65 million overrun on the budget for the sale—$210 million was the budget for the sale costs and the ultimate cost was $275 million. The Auditor-General found that the global coordinators, the people who organised and managed the sale on behalf of the government, were chosen before a fee arrangement was outlined and that a fee was negotiated with them after the conclusion of that effective tender process. In other words, we had, I suppose, a beauty contest—all the various bidders were there putting forward proposals as to how they would proceed with the sale and what fees they would charge. An outcome was negotiated with a consortium and then, after those people were designated as the successful tenderers who would conduct the sale, negotiations were entered into with them for the price, the fees, that they would be paid in order to do the sale. Hardly surprisingly, the Auditor-General concluded that this was a rather peculiar way to conduct a public sector privatisation; a very peculiar way to choose somebody to be the global coordinator of that privatisation.
But the story gets worse; the story gets even more peculiar. We see, for example, that the success benchmarks that were set by the Office of Asset Sales to determine what the success fees would be were actually set below those that in effect were recommended by the 1996 scoping study and below those that were recommended by the March 1997 Office of Asset Sales recommendations. The Auditor-General concluded that this cost the taxpayer somewhere between $5.4 million and $10.3 
 million. You might think that is small in the context of a privatisation that ultimately yielded in the vicinity of $14 billion, but nonetheless that is still $5 million to $10 million worth of taxpayers' money that this government threw away.
But the story does not end there and it gets even more peculiar. Almost $500,000 in success fees was paid to the global coordinators, most of them with respect to shares that they gave away. These people got paid money to give shares away. I would not mind getting a job like that. It is pretty easy money if you are giving shares away. But that is what happened. Four hundred and sixty-eight thousand dollars of the success fees related to bonus shares that were given away to Telstra staff members as part of the loyalty program. They got paid $468,000 to give shares away. Another $26,000 of the success fees related to shares that were not sold.
So they managed to cop a pretty hefty whack for shares that they gave away and an extra little bonus for shares that never went anywhere that the government still owns. A total of about $500,000 has been paid in success fees, which was clearly unnecessary and—to rub salt into the wound—was actually not obligatory under the contract between the Commonwealth and the global coordinators. According to the Office of Asset Sales, it was simply understood that they would have to pay this money. Five hundred thousand dollars of taxpayers' money later, you have got a situation where these people have been paid to give shares away or paid for not organising the sale of shares.
The international roadshow that was undertaken to promote the sale overseas was originally budgeted at $1 million and it ended up costing $3.1 million, $600,000 of which related to limousines, private plane hire and the like. Some of the money that was spent, it was ultimately concluded by the Auditor-General, did not relate to the sale of Telstra. The Auditor-General concluded that this expenditure was `not independently verified through appropriate supporting documentation and an effective audit trail was not maintained'. 
And the story continues. Five million dollars worth of underwriting fees was paid with respect to shares for which no underwriting was actually required. There is a range of other minor losses: $700,000 lost because no foreign exchange hedging occurred with respect to certain payments to subcontractors which should have occurred. There were delays in processing applications. I have spoken to people who worked in the call centre and the like at the time and they said it was simply chaotic. These delays cost the taxpayer somewhere between $1.2 million and $2 million, according to the Auditor-General.
So the first sale—however much it has been touted as a great success for the government—organisationally and in terms of the interests of the taxpayer, was a total fiasco. But the critical issue in all this was that the first sale was massively underpriced. The Auditor-General found that, in spite of the fact that obviously you cannot get these things precisely right—obviously share markets are not easy to predict and hindsight is a wonderful thing—the first tranche sale was massively underpriced.
If you want a really good way of seeing this, if you want a really simple way of identifying this, all you have to do is look at the explanatory material for the proposed sale of the second tranche, which is 16.7 per cent, and see that it is estimated that that will yield somewhere between $10 billion and $15 billion. The first tranche was 33 per cent, double that, and what did it yield? Fourteen billion dollars. In other words, we are likely to get the same proceeds for the second tranche of 16½ per cent that we got for the first tranche of 33 per cent.
The Auditor-General found that the value of Telstra shares post-sale had increased 160 times the all-ordinaries index increase over that period. It is no wonder that we have seen a spate of articles in the quality media about how the Minister for Finance and Administration is the pin-up boy of the big end of town. He has been throwing money in their direction like a man with no arms. He is having a great time promoting his reputation and making people feel good about privatisation, 
 but ultimately at the expense of the Australian taxpayer and the Australian government.
I turn to the question of the second tranche. It is interesting to see that the government has not learned from what has gone on in the sale of the first tranche of Telstra. We see that it is estimated in the explanatory material that roughly 1.5 per cent to two per cent of the proceeds of the sale of the second tranche, or ultimately the balance of Telstra, will be required for sale costs—commissions, fees and the like.
It does not take much complicated arithmetic to work out that that is going to amount to somewhere in the vicinity of $800 million to $1.1 billion. So, in other words, we have a billion dollar bonus for bankers in the second sale of Telstra. It is interesting to compare it with the social bonus that we heard talked about earlier tonight, which is estimated to be $671 million. So we have a social bonus, $670 million-odd, dwarfed by the bankers' bonus.
From a broader point of view, it is worth querying the logic, the basis, on which these sales are conducted and the fact that they are conducted on a percentage fee basis, which seems out of all proportion to the associated obligations, the risk, the management activities, that the intermediaries who are employed to do it actually undertake. When you are talking about a billion dollars to sell shares in a market that is already established, that is already mature, that is already traded, you really have to question the value for money that the taxpayer is getting out of this. Again, it does not matter if this is only a small percentage of the total. You are talking about $1 billion, some of which could ultimately be used to very good effect for other things.
It is abundantly clear that there will be a full sale. We have a fig leaf of an inquiry put there to satisfy some of the elements in the coalition's backbench and to pretend to the electorate at the previous election that the coalition perhaps was not going to sell all of Telstra. It is clear that there will be a full sale. The fact that makes that blindingly obvious is that in this legislation there is no requirement for that issue to come back to parliament. The minister simply decides 
 whether or not there will be another 51 per cent sale, declares that the inquiry has found that it is quite all right to go ahead—maybe with one or two additional sops, a bit more money here, a little extra social bonus there—and it will go ahead.
This is another example—it is not the first—of a major privatisation being done by this government without any reference to parliament. We saw it with the Australian National sale, where the legislation that was put through the parliament effectively said, `The ministers are empowered to do whatever they like,' including being empowered to, by decree, repeal an existing act of parliament. Even worse, we saw it with the sale of the Australian National Line. Legislation was presented to the parliament. It went through this House and it went over to the Senate and it sat there. It is still sitting there, but ANL of course has been sold in the meantime.
The social bonus adds up, as I said, over a period of five years to $670 million—the odd rural transaction centre, untimed local calls here and there, some money for isolated communities, regional Internet access and the like, all of them good things. But the question that has to be asked about that is: what follows? It will be useful in the short term, it sounds good, and it is very politically effective if you have a few disaffected supporters, disaffected backbenchers, in regional Australia. But there is no overriding vision of the future of telecommunications in this country. There is nothing about content. Content is going to be the future, not only of this industry but ultimately a very big driver of the Australian economy. Yet there is nothing about generating content. Some of the good ideas on that issue that were in Creative Nation, the program initiated by the former Keating government, contrary to promises that were made by John Howard, are being unravelled.
There is a range of broader issues that all of us—not only government but the opposition as well—have to address in this debate, a range of very difficult issues. We have now got a hybrid, not courtesy of what we have created—nothing to do with us. Whether we like it or not, we have now got a hybrid. We 
 have got a part publicly owned, part privately owned organisation which is involved in everything from the provision of the most basic telecommunications services, which are essential to ordinary civilised existence in our society, through to a fairly substantial range of entrepreneurial activities. It functions, for example, through Telstra Big Pond as an ISP, an Internet service provider. There are a range of other activities going on through Telstra that clearly are not essential telecommunications services, certainly not at this stage. In the more distant future they may well end up being so. None of us knows precisely how society will evolve.
We are going to have to confront the question not of who owns Telstra but of what should Telstra do. What activities, particularly if it remains part public owned, should it be involved in? Ownership is ultimately the best form of regulation. Part ownership, even if it is 67 per cent, more so if it is 51 per cent, clearly is a very limited weapon in pursuing your objectives through ownership. So we have an issue we have to think very carefully about—the future of telecommunications in this country, the future role that Telstra will play, particularly if, as the Labor Party believes it should, it continues to act as a publicly owned provider of a very diverse range of telecommunications services.
At first blush it is worth considering the question of structural separation. I think there are some fairly strong arguments as to why that is going to have to happen in some form, regardless of whether Telstra ends up being in part public ownership or fully private ownership. The great difficulty with that, which we will have to wrestle with, is precisely how do you separate it, given that the natural monopoly component of Telstra is changing all the time, the competition with respect to infrastructure and services is blurring the division between the two and technology is changing all the time? So defining things like `a basic telecommunications service' or `an essential service' is becoming increasingly difficult.
We will have issues from the other players in the market about the connection between some of Telstra's entrepreneurial activities 
 and its dominance as the primary infrastructure provider, notwithstanding the ACCC regulatory framework. So these are all things that we are going to have to think about, things that will be very important issues in the future of telecommunications in this country. Yet what we are getting at the moment is essentially a fire sale that is driven by politics—driven by ideology, yes, but ultimately driven by politics—driven by the desire to have a nice little bundle of money to throw around from time to time at elections, to throw at some natural constituencies through natural heritage trusts and the like, fix up a few dams here and throw a few bits of money at various things there, not the right things to do by the environment but capable of being portrayed in that way, with no vision whatsoever for the future of communications, which ultimately is going to be the driver of Australia's economic prosperity. This industry more than any other will determine our future economic prosperity. This government has no serious vision about what it is going to do.
I would now like to turn to the question of debt. The primary reason that is portrayed for why we should be selling Telstra is that we have an allegedly vast amount of government debt and that if we sell Telstra we will be able to pay off a lot of it. The full sale would, on current market value, realise somewhere in the vicinity of $53 billion. Current net Commonwealth debt is about $83 billion.
Mr Hardgrave interjecting—
—You will hear a bit more about that in a minute, if you shut up and listen. If the surplus is maintained and other asset sales continue as proposed, that debt will be significantly lower. But, of course, the dividend that Telstra provides will be lost. Particularly as Telstra is currently earning a fairly low rate of return on capital, given its market capitalisation, that is a very foolish decision on the part of this government. Around the markets at the moment, the suggestion is being made that Telstra really should have a rate of return of somewhere around $6 to $9 billion per annum, which to some degree ignores its recent monopoly and public sector background. Nonetheless, that pressure will continue to build.
It is time that we had a bit of rational debate on public sector debt in this country. The reason why the conservatives are opposed to debt has nothing to do with fiscal responsibility, government accounting or anything like that; the reason they are opposed to debt is that they are opposed to government. They are opposed to government intervention, governments doing things and the collective provision of community services. They are opposed to redistribution.
